etymologies: early 17th century. Origin unknown. Perhaps compare paw and -y

definitions: A clever or deceptive movement; a nimble gesture; a flourish. In later use also: an exaggerated or excessive movement; a commotion, a bustle, a flurry.

etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in Charles Cotton (1630–1687), poet and translator. From French pavie, probably from Pavie (French Pavie, Occitan Pavia), the name of a town in the department of Gers, Southern France
